speaker: CORIN
text: And how like you this shepherd’s life, Master

speaker: CORIN
text: Touchstone?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: Truly, shepherd, in respect of itself, it is a

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: good life; but in respect that it is a shepherd’s life, it

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: is naught. In respect that it is solitary, I like it very

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: well; but in respect that it is private, it is a very vile

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: life. Now in respect it is in the fields, it pleaseth me

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: well; but in respect it is not in the court, it is

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: tedious. As it is a spare life, look you, it fits my

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: humor well; but as there is no more plenty in it, it

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: goes much against my stomach. Hast any philosophy

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: in thee, shepherd?

speaker: CORIN
text: No more but that I know the more one sickens,

speaker: CORIN
text: the worse at ease he is, and that he that wants

speaker: CORIN
text: money, means, and content is without three good

speaker: CORIN
text: friends; that the property of rain is to wet, and fire

speaker: CORIN
text: to burn; that good pasture makes fat sheep; and that

speaker: CORIN
text: a great cause of the night is lack of the sun; that he

speaker: CORIN
text: that hath learned no wit by nature nor art may

speaker: CORIN
text: complain of good breeding or comes of a very dull

speaker: CORIN
text: kindred.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: Such a one is a natural philosopher. Wast

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: ever in court, shepherd?

speaker: CORIN
text: No, truly.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: Then thou art damned.

speaker: CORIN
text: Nay, I hope.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: Truly, thou art damned, like an ill-roasted

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: egg, all on one side.

speaker: CORIN
text: For not being at court? Your reason.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: Why, if thou never wast at court, thou

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: never saw’st good manners; if thou never saw’st

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: good manners, then thy manners must be wicked,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: and wickedness is sin, and sin is damnation. Thou

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: art in a parlous state, shepherd.

speaker: CORIN
text: Not a whit, Touchstone. Those that are good

speaker: CORIN
text: manners at the court are as ridiculous in the

speaker: CORIN
text: country as the behavior of the country is most

speaker: CORIN
text: mockable at the court. You told me you salute not at

speaker: CORIN
text: the court but you kiss your hands. That courtesy

speaker: CORIN
text: would be uncleanly if courtiers were shepherds.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: Instance, briefly. Come, instance.

speaker: CORIN
text: Why, we are still handling our ewes, and their

speaker: CORIN
text: fells, you know, are greasy.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: Why, do not your courtier’s hands sweat?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: And is not the grease of a mutton as wholesome as

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: the sweat of a man? Shallow, shallow. A better

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: instance, I say. Come.

speaker: CORIN
text: Besides, our hands are hard.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: Your lips will feel them the sooner. Shallow

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: again. A more sounder instance. Come.

speaker: CORIN
text: And they are often tarred over with the surgery

speaker: CORIN
text: of our sheep; and would you have us kiss tar? The

speaker: CORIN
text: courtier’s hands are perfumed with civet.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: Most shallow man. Thou worms’ meat in

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: respect of a good piece of flesh, indeed. Learn of the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: wise and perpend: civet is of a baser birth than tar,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: the very uncleanly flux of a cat. Mend the instance,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: shepherd.

speaker: CORIN
text: You have too courtly a wit for me. I’ll rest.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: Wilt thou rest damned? God help thee,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: shallow man. God make incision in thee; thou art

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: raw.

speaker: CORIN
text: Sir, I am a true laborer. I earn that I eat, get that

speaker: CORIN
text: I wear, owe no man hate, envy no man’s happiness,

speaker: CORIN
text: glad of other men’s good, content with my harm,

speaker: CORIN
text: and the greatest of my pride is to see my ewes graze

speaker: CORIN
text: and my lambs suck.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: That is another simple sin in you, to bring

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: the ewes and the rams together and to offer to get

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: your living by the copulation of cattle; to be bawd to

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: a bell-wether and to betray a she-lamb of a twelvemonth

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: to a crooked-pated old cuckoldly ram, out of

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: all reasonable match. If thou be’st not damned for

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: this, the devil himself will have no shepherds. I

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: cannot see else how thou shouldst ’scape.

speaker: CORIN
text: Here comes young Master Ganymede, my new

speaker: CORIN
text: mistress’s brother.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: I’ll rhyme you so eight years together,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: dinners and suppers and sleeping hours excepted.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: It is the right butter-women’s rank to market.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Out, fool.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: For a taste:

speaker: TOUCHSTONE

If

speaker: TOUCHSTONE

So

speaker: TOUCHSTONE

Wintered
               
              garments
               
              must

              ;

speaker: TOUCHSTONE

So

              slender

speaker: TOUCHSTONE

They
               
              that

              must

              and

              ;

speaker: TOUCHSTONE

Then
               
              to
               
              cart

              .

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text:
Sweetest
               
              nut
               
              hath
               
              sourest
               
              rind
              ;

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text:
Such
               
              a
               
              nut
               
              is
               
              Rosalind
              .

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text:
He
               
              that
               
              sweetest
               
              rose
               
              will
               
              find

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text:
Must
               
              find
               
              love’s
               
              prick
              ,
               
              and
               
              Rosalind
              .

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: This is the very false gallop of verses. Why do you

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: infect yourself with them?

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Peace, you dull fool. I found

speaker: ROSALIND
text: them on a tree.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: Truly, the tree yields bad fruit.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: I’ll graft it with you, and

speaker: ROSALIND
text: then I shall graft it with a medlar. Then it will be

speaker: ROSALIND
text: the earliest fruit i’ th’ country, for you’ll be rotten

speaker: ROSALIND
text: ere you be half ripe, and that’s the right virtue of

speaker: ROSALIND
text: the medlar.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: You have said, but whether wisely or no,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: let the forest judge.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Peace. Here comes my sister

speaker: ROSALIND
text: reading. Stand aside.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: O most gentle Jupiter, what

speaker: ROSALIND
text: tedious homily of love have you wearied your parishioners

speaker: ROSALIND
text: withal, and never cried “Have patience,

speaker: ROSALIND
text: good people!”

speaker: CELIA
text: How now?—Back, friends. Shepherd,

speaker: CELIA
text: go off a little.—Go with him, sirrah.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: Come, shepherd, let us make an honorable

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: retreat, though not with bag and baggage, yet

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text: with scrip and scrippage.

speaker: CELIA
text: Didst thou hear these verses?

speaker: ROSALIND
text: O yes, I heard them all, and more too, for

speaker: ROSALIND
text: some of them had in them more feet than the verses

speaker: ROSALIND
text: would bear.

speaker: CELIA
text: That’s no matter. The feet might bear the verses.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Ay, but the feet were lame and could not

speaker: ROSALIND
text: bear themselves without the verse, and therefore

speaker: ROSALIND
text: stood lamely in the verse.

speaker: CELIA
text: But didst thou hear without wondering how thy

speaker: CELIA
text: name should be hanged and carved upon these

speaker: CELIA
text: trees?

speaker: ROSALIND
text: I was seven of the nine days out of the

speaker: ROSALIND
text: wonder before you came, for look here what I

speaker: ROSALIND
text: found on a palm tree.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: I was never so berhymed since Pythagoras’

speaker: ROSALIND
text: time that I was an Irish rat, which I can hardly

speaker: ROSALIND
text: remember.

speaker: CELIA
text: Trow you who hath done this?

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Is it a man?

speaker: CELIA
text: And a chain, that you once wore, about his neck.

speaker: CELIA
text: Change you color?

speaker: ROSALIND
text: I prithee, who?

speaker: CELIA
text: O Lord, Lord, it is a hard matter for friends to

speaker: CELIA
text: meet, but mountains may be removed with earthquakes

speaker: CELIA
text: and so encounter.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Nay, but who is it?

speaker: CELIA
text: Is it possible?

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Nay, I prithee now, with most petitionary

speaker: ROSALIND
text: vehemence, tell me who it is.

speaker: CELIA
text: O wonderful, wonderful, and most wonderful

speaker: CELIA
text: wonderful, and yet again wonderful, and after that

speaker: CELIA
text: out of all whooping!

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Good my complexion, dost thou think

speaker: ROSALIND
text: though I am caparisoned like a man, I have a

speaker: ROSALIND
text: doublet and hose in my disposition? One inch of

speaker: ROSALIND
text: delay more is a South Sea of discovery. I prithee,

speaker: ROSALIND
text: tell me who is it quickly, and speak apace. I would

speaker: ROSALIND
text: thou couldst stammer, that thou might’st pour this

speaker: ROSALIND
text: concealed man out of thy mouth as wine comes out

speaker: ROSALIND
text: of a narrow-mouthed bottle—either too much at

speaker: ROSALIND
text: once, or none at all. I prithee take the cork out of

speaker: ROSALIND
text: thy mouth, that I may drink thy tidings.

speaker: CELIA
text: So you may put a man in your belly.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Is he of God’s making? What manner of

speaker: ROSALIND
text: man? Is his head worth a hat, or his chin worth a

speaker: ROSALIND
text: beard?

speaker: CELIA
text: Nay, he hath but a little beard.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Why, God will send more, if the man will be

speaker: ROSALIND
text: thankful. Let me stay the growth of his beard, if

speaker: ROSALIND
text: thou delay me not the knowledge of his chin.

speaker: CELIA
text: It is young Orlando, that tripped up the wrestler’s

speaker: CELIA
text: heels and your heart both in an instant.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Nay, but the devil take mocking. Speak sad

speaker: ROSALIND
text: brow and true maid.

speaker: CELIA
text: I’ faith, coz, ’tis he.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Orlando?

speaker: CELIA
text: Orlando.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Alas the day, what shall I do with my doublet

speaker: ROSALIND
text: and hose? What did he when thou saw’st him? What

speaker: ROSALIND
text: said he? How looked he? Wherein went he? What

speaker: ROSALIND
text: makes he here? Did he ask for me? Where remains

speaker: ROSALIND
text: he? How parted he with thee? And when shalt thou

speaker: ROSALIND
text: see him again? Answer me in one word.

speaker: CELIA
text: You must borrow me Gargantua’s mouth first.

speaker: CELIA
text: ’Tis a word too great for any mouth of this age’s size.

speaker: CELIA
text: To say ay and no to these particulars is more than to

speaker: CELIA
text: answer in a catechism.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: But doth he know that I am in this forest and

speaker: ROSALIND
text: in man’s apparel? Looks he as freshly as he did the

speaker: ROSALIND
text: day he wrestled?

speaker: CELIA
text: It is as easy to count atomies as to resolve the

speaker: CELIA
text: propositions of a lover. But take a taste of my

speaker: CELIA
text: finding him, and relish it with good observance. I

speaker: CELIA
text: found him under a tree like a dropped acorn.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: It may well be called Jove’s tree when it

speaker: ROSALIND
text: drops forth such fruit.

speaker: CELIA
text: Give me audience, good madam.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Proceed.

speaker: CELIA
text: There lay he, stretched along like a wounded

speaker: CELIA
text: knight.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Though it be pity to see such a sight, it well

speaker: ROSALIND
text: becomes the ground.

speaker: CELIA
text: Cry “holla” to thy tongue, I prithee. It curvets

speaker: CELIA
text: unseasonably. He was furnished like a hunter.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: O, ominous! He comes to kill my heart.

speaker: CELIA
text: I would sing my song without a burden. Thou

speaker: CELIA
text: bring’st me out of tune.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Do you not know I am a woman? When I

speaker: ROSALIND
text: think, I must speak. Sweet, say on.

speaker: CELIA
text: You bring me out.

speaker: CELIA
text: Soft, comes he not here?

speaker: ROSALIND
text: ’Tis he. Slink by, and note him.

speaker: JAQUES
text: I thank you for your company,

speaker: JAQUES
text: but, good faith, I had as lief have been myself alone.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: And so had I, but yet, for fashion sake, I

speaker: ORLANDO
text: thank you too for your society.

speaker: JAQUES
text: God be wi’ you. Let’s meet as little as we can.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: I do desire we may be better strangers.

speaker: JAQUES
text: I pray you mar no more trees with writing love

speaker: JAQUES
text: songs in their barks.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: I pray you mar no more of my verses with

speaker: ORLANDO
text: reading them ill-favoredly.

speaker: JAQUES
text: Rosalind is your love’s name?

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Yes, just.

speaker: JAQUES
text: I do not like her name.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: There was no thought of pleasing you when

speaker: ORLANDO
text: she was christened.

speaker: JAQUES
text: What stature is she of?

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Just as high as my heart.

speaker: JAQUES
text: You are full of pretty answers. Have you not

speaker: JAQUES
text: been acquainted with goldsmiths’ wives and

speaker: JAQUES
text: conned them out of rings?

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Not so. But I answer you right painted cloth,

speaker: ORLANDO
text: from whence you have studied your questions.

speaker: JAQUES
text: You have a nimble wit. I think ’twas made of

speaker: JAQUES
text: Atalanta’s heels. Will you sit down with me? And we

speaker: JAQUES
text: two will rail against our mistress the world and all

speaker: JAQUES
text: our misery.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: I will chide no breather in the world but

speaker: ORLANDO
text: myself, against whom I know most faults.

speaker: JAQUES
text: The worst fault you have is to be in love.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: ’Tis a fault I will not change for your best

speaker: ORLANDO
text: virtue. I am weary of you.

speaker: JAQUES
text: By my troth, I was seeking for a fool when I

speaker: JAQUES
text: found you.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: He is drowned in the brook. Look but in, and

speaker: ORLANDO
text: you shall see him.

speaker: JAQUES
text: There I shall see mine own figure.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Which I take to be either a fool or a cipher.

speaker: JAQUES
text: I’ll tarry no longer with you. Farewell, good

speaker: JAQUES
text: Signior Love.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: I am glad of your departure. Adieu, good

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Monsieur Melancholy.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: I will speak to him like a

speaker: ROSALIND
text: saucy lackey, and under that habit play the knave

speaker: ROSALIND
text:
with him.
                 
                As
                 
                Ganymede
                .
               Do you hear, forester?

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Very well. What would you?

speaker: ROSALIND
text: I pray you, what is ’t

speaker: ROSALIND
text: o’clock?

speaker: ORLANDO
text: You should ask me what time o’ day. There’s

speaker: ORLANDO
text: no clock in the forest.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Then there is no true lover

speaker: ROSALIND
text: in the forest; else sighing every minute and

speaker: ROSALIND
text: groaning every hour would detect the lazy foot of

speaker: ROSALIND
text: time as well as a clock.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: And why not the swift foot of time? Had not

speaker: ORLANDO
text: that been as proper?

speaker: ROSALIND
text: By no means, sir. Time

speaker: ROSALIND
text: travels in divers paces with divers persons. I’ll tell

speaker: ROSALIND
text: you who time ambles withal, who time trots withal,

speaker: ROSALIND
text: who time gallops withal, and who he stands still

speaker: ROSALIND
text: withal.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: I prithee, who doth he trot withal?

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Marry, he trots hard with a

speaker: ROSALIND
text: young maid between the contract of her marriage

speaker: ROSALIND
text: and the day it is solemnized. If the interim be but a

speaker: ROSALIND
text: se’nnight, time’s pace is so hard that it seems the

speaker: ROSALIND
text: length of seven year.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Who ambles time withal?

speaker: ROSALIND
text: With a priest that lacks Latin

speaker: ROSALIND
text: and a rich man that hath not the gout, for the one

speaker: ROSALIND
text: sleeps easily because he cannot study, and the other

speaker: ROSALIND
text: lives merrily because he feels no pain—the one

speaker: ROSALIND
text: lacking the burden of lean and wasteful learning,

speaker: ROSALIND
text: the other knowing no burden of heavy tedious

speaker: ROSALIND
text: penury. These time ambles withal.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Who doth he gallop withal?

speaker: ROSALIND
text: With a thief to the gallows,

speaker: ROSALIND
text: for though he go as softly as foot can fall, he thinks

speaker: ROSALIND
text: himself too soon there.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Who stays it still withal?

speaker: ROSALIND
text: With lawyers in the vacation,

speaker: ROSALIND
text: for they sleep between term and term, and

speaker: ROSALIND
text: then they perceive not how time moves.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Where dwell you, pretty youth?

speaker: ROSALIND
text: With this shepherdess, my

speaker: ROSALIND
text: sister, here in the skirts of the forest, like fringe

speaker: ROSALIND
text: upon a petticoat.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Are you native of this place?

speaker: ROSALIND
text: As the cony that you see

speaker: ROSALIND
text: dwell where she is kindled.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Your accent is something finer than you

speaker: ORLANDO
text: could purchase in so removed a dwelling.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: I have been told so of many.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: But indeed an old religious uncle of mine taught

speaker: ROSALIND
text: me to speak, who was in his youth an inland man,

speaker: ROSALIND
text: one that knew courtship too well, for there he fell in

speaker: ROSALIND
text: love. I have heard him read many lectures against it,

speaker: ROSALIND
text: and I thank God I am not a woman, to be touched

speaker: ROSALIND
text: with so many giddy offenses as he hath generally

speaker: ROSALIND
text: taxed their whole sex withal.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Can you remember any of the principal evils

speaker: ORLANDO
text: that he laid to the charge of women?

speaker: ROSALIND
text: There were none principal.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: They were all like one another as halfpence are,

speaker: ROSALIND
text: every one fault seeming monstrous till his fellow

speaker: ROSALIND
text: fault came to match it.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: I prithee recount some of them.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: No, I will not cast away my

speaker: ROSALIND
text: physic but on those that are sick. There is a man

speaker: ROSALIND
text: haunts the forest that abuses our young plants with

speaker: ROSALIND
text: carving “Rosalind” on their barks, hangs odes upon

speaker: ROSALIND
text: hawthorns and elegies on brambles, all, forsooth,

speaker: ROSALIND
text: deifying the name of Rosalind. If I could meet

speaker: ROSALIND
text: that fancy-monger, I would give him some good

speaker: ROSALIND
text: counsel, for he seems to have the quotidian of love

speaker: ROSALIND
text: upon him.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: I am he that is so love-shaked. I pray you tell

speaker: ORLANDO
text: me your remedy.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: There is none of my uncle’s

speaker: ROSALIND
text: marks upon you. He taught me how to know a man

speaker: ROSALIND
text: in love, in which cage of rushes I am sure you are

speaker: ROSALIND
text: not prisoner.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: What were his marks?

speaker: ROSALIND
text: A lean cheek, which you

speaker: ROSALIND
text: have not; a blue eye and sunken, which you have

speaker: ROSALIND
text: not; an unquestionable spirit, which you have not; a

speaker: ROSALIND
text: beard neglected, which you have not—but I pardon

speaker: ROSALIND
text: you for that, for simply your having in beard is a

speaker: ROSALIND
text: younger brother’s revenue. Then your hose should

speaker: ROSALIND
text: be ungartered, your bonnet unbanded, your sleeve

speaker: ROSALIND
text: unbuttoned, your shoe untied, and everything

speaker: ROSALIND
text: about you demonstrating a careless desolation. But

speaker: ROSALIND
text: you are no such man. You are rather point-device in

speaker: ROSALIND
text: your accouterments, as loving yourself than seeming

speaker: ROSALIND
text: the lover of any other.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Fair youth, I would I could make thee believe

speaker: ORLANDO
text: I love.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Me believe it? You may as

speaker: ROSALIND
text: soon make her that you love believe it, which I

speaker: ROSALIND
text: warrant she is apter to do than to confess she does.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: That is one of the points in the which women still

speaker: ROSALIND
text: give the lie to their consciences. But, in good sooth,

speaker: ROSALIND
text: are you he that hangs the verses on the trees

speaker: ROSALIND
text: wherein Rosalind is so admired?

speaker: ORLANDO
text: I swear to thee, youth, by the white hand of

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Rosalind, I am that he, that unfortunate he.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: But are you so much in love

speaker: ROSALIND
text: as your rhymes speak?

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Neither rhyme nor reason can express how

speaker: ORLANDO
text: much.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Love is merely a madness,

speaker: ROSALIND
text: and, I tell you, deserves as well a dark house and a

speaker: ROSALIND
text: whip as madmen do; and the reason why they are

speaker: ROSALIND
text: not so punished and cured is that the lunacy is so

speaker: ROSALIND
text: ordinary that the whippers are in love too. Yet I

speaker: ROSALIND
text: profess curing it by counsel.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Did you ever cure any so?

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Yes, one, and in this manner.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: He was to imagine me his love, his mistress,

speaker: ROSALIND
text: and I set him every day to woo me; at which time

speaker: ROSALIND
text: would I, being but a moonish youth, grieve, be

speaker: ROSALIND
text: effeminate, changeable, longing and liking, proud,

speaker: ROSALIND
text: fantastical, apish, shallow, inconstant, full of tears,

speaker: ROSALIND
text: full of smiles; for every passion something, and for

speaker: ROSALIND
text: no passion truly anything, as boys and women are,

speaker: ROSALIND
text: for the most part, cattle of this color; would now

speaker: ROSALIND
text: like him, now loathe him; then entertain him, then

speaker: ROSALIND
text: forswear him; now weep for him, then spit at him,

speaker: ROSALIND
text: that I drave my suitor from his mad humor of love

speaker: ROSALIND
text: to a living humor of madness, which was to forswear

speaker: ROSALIND
text: the full stream of the world and to live in a

speaker: ROSALIND
text: nook merely monastic. And thus I cured him, and

speaker: ROSALIND
text: this way will I take upon me to wash your liver as

speaker: ROSALIND
text: clean as a sound sheep’s heart, that there shall not

speaker: ROSALIND
text: be one spot of love in ’t.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: I would not be cured, youth.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: I would cure you if you

speaker: ROSALIND
text: would but call me Rosalind and come every day to

speaker: ROSALIND
text: my cote and woo me.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Now, by the faith of my love, I will. Tell me

speaker: ORLANDO
text: where it is.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Go with me to it, and I’ll

speaker: ROSALIND
text: show it you; and by the way you shall tell me where

speaker: ROSALIND
text: in the forest you live. Will you go?

speaker: ORLANDO
text: With all my heart, good youth.

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Nay, you must call me

speaker: ROSALIND
text: Rosalind.—Come, sister, will you go?
